Immerse yourself in the essence of London's heritage with our captivating distillery tours, exclusive events, and bespoke private hire options. Indulge your senses with a shopping experience featuring unique gin-related treasures, then unwind with expertly crafted cocktails that showcase the true spirit of our city. At Beefeater Gin Distillery, we invite you to explore the rich history and artisanal craft behind every bottle, as we continue to embody 'The Spirit of London'. Join us for an unforgettable journey into the world of gin, where tradition meets innovation, and every sip tells a story. Book your visit today and let London's spirit move you.
address: 20 Montford Place, London SE11 5DE England

top_reviews.title: Fab space and welcoming staff
top_reviews.review: We used the Beefeater meeting space on a Saturday and had the most amazing day. The staff were attentive, kind and generous. They provided well for all our allergen needs. There was an abundance of food and it displayed beautifully. The space itself was a fantastic open space with good natural light. We couldn't have been more pleased with the space and the reception we received. We will definitely use them again.

top_reviews.title: Enjoyable and informative
top_reviews.review: Such an amazing experience, got to see where all the gin is made, a gin tasting experience (including one that is only available at the Beefeater distillery) and also a museum tour. Finished with a lovely gin and tonic (or lemonade) and popcorn!!!

top_reviews.title: Great day out!!
top_reviews.review: Highly recommend. I'm not the biggest fan of gin, but still I had such a great time and want to come back! The museum was fun and appreciated that you could go at your own pace. The tasting was my favourite part - Katharina was a great host and kept us engaged throughout, and the gin was nice too! The distillery itself is amazing and was a very cool look into behind the scenes.

top_reviews.title: Beefeaters Distillery Tour
top_reviews.review: Whole experience was really neat and well worth it. Self guided tour was very informative and interesting. Our guide, Katerina, for the tasting and distillery tour was excellent! Overall a great way to spend a couple hours learning about London gin.

top_reviews.title: Educational
top_reviews.review: Very nice distillery. The self guided tour was well done and informative. The guided part was nice as well. I really enjoyed the tasting as we got to touch, feel and smell the botanicals used for beefeater gin. I wish we could have sampled the flavored gin as well. We did get a gin and tonic at the end. It was something I would do again however it was out of the way and somewhat hard to get too. It’s about a 20 plus min walk from the underground. Possibly closer on bus but we never figured out the bus system.

top_reviews.title: Great day out!
top_reviews.review: Had planned to go earlier in the year as it was a mother's day present - just mum and me. Ended up being on the 16th December. Just as well though, we were the only people booked in on that day so it was like a VIP experience! Served drinks in the main reception desk area and then after a couple of more drinks started the tour early. The very knowledgeable Matt, our guide for the tour, met us at the end of the self guided museum exhibition bit and walked us round the distillery and answered all of our questions. The tasting portion came next and we were guided through how to taste and smell the different flavours and aromas of the different gins made at Beefeater which were all very nice. A really nice G&T each and then a cocktail of our choice (Martinez) was served afterwards as we all had a good chat about all things gin and booze. It ran slightly overtime but Matt didn't mind. Neither did we! It was an excellent day out and I would highly recommend to anyone thinking of going. The staff were superb all round and we both could have stayed there for a few more! Got given some money off vouchers at the very end in the gift shop for some 2 for 1 drink offers in a little boozer round the corner called The Pilgrim. All in all, it couldn't have been a better day out for us. Well pleased!

top_reviews.title: Girls Trip to the Distllery!
top_reviews.review: We kicked off our recent girls' trip to Beefeater's Distillery with a burst of excitement, arriving promptly as the showroom opened, even beating our tour schedule by a good hour. The staff, thankfully, were on the ball and accommodated our early enthusiasm by serving up our welcome cocktails ahead of the official start time. The showroom itself left a good impression with its pristine cleanliness. However, the bathroom, while generally tidy, had a few hiccups with broken faucets. A word of caution: the water flows scorching hot, so handle with care. The "museum" section didn't disappoint, offering an insightful dive into the history of gin in the UK. It provided a solid historical foundation with a unique twist. Our guide, Matt, deserves a shoutout for keeping the tour engaging and informative. Despite the group being a bit reserved, he maintained a steady pace, ensuring we got the most out of the experience. The tour culminated in a tasting session where Matt, doubling as our bartender, showcased not only his knowledge but also his bartending skills. His recommendations for pairings and insights into his favorite local bars added a personal touch to the experience. We even managed to check out at least two of his recommended spots. In the end, while I can't say I've been converted into a diehard gin enthusiast, the trip was undeniably enjoyable and educational. Beefeater's Distillery provided a unique perspective on gin, and Matt's expertise added that extra flair, making it a great outing overall. Cheers to learning something new and having a good time!

top_reviews.title: Thank you Matthew for an amazing tour!!
top_reviews.review: Myself and my friends went for a bday trip and we had such an amazing time. Matthew and the rest of the team were so lovely. We have done a few tours before and hands down this was the best tour ever. Thank you again Matthew for the amazing tour

top_reviews.title: Beefeater tour
top_reviews.review: Amazing tour. Discovering everything about the Beefeater Gin. After the museum part you start the guided tour. Helen was our guide and she told us everything we wanted to know about the gin. We loved the tasting part of the tour.

top_reviews.title: Wonderful afternoon sampling this historic gin
top_reviews.review: Fantastic trip to Beefeater only 10 ish mins walk from Vauxhall and Oval stations. Helen was a fantastic and knowledgeable guide for the tastings and the distillery part of the tour. The self guided portion was informative and well laid out. Would definitely recommend! Amazing value for money and a lovely G&T to finish the tour off.

name: Old Royal Naval College
description: EXPLORE 600 YEARS OF HISTORY AT THIS UNESCO WORLD HERITAGE SITE. Be wowed by the breath-taking Painted Hall, known as the UK’s Sistine Chapel, at the Old Royal Naval College. (Guided Painted Hall talks run every 30 minutes from 11am – 4pm. or audio media guide available in English, French, Spanish, Italian, Mandarin, German, and Japanese + British Sign Language). The buildings and grounds are one of the most popular filming locations in the UK. Many of your favourite blockbusters have been filmed here including The Crown, Les Misérables, Napolean, Bridgerton and many more. Book a film tour to discover real-life filming locations and behind the scenes secrets. You can choose to join an award winning tour of this magnificent landmark in the heart of the Greenwich Maritime UNESCO World Heritage Site. Tours depart from the visitor centre on the hour from 11am – 3pm. Learn of the fascinating 600-year story, including being the birthplace of Henry VIII and Queen Elizabeth I.
category: Historic Sites Architectural Buildings History Museums
address: Cutty Sark Gardens University of Greenwich, London SE10 9NN England

top_reviews.title: THE OLD NAVEL COLLEGE!! A TOUR WREN DOME!!
top_reviews.review: I have always liked this Unesco World Heritage Site, The Old Navel College, for me standing proud at the bottom of the Royal Observatory and Greenwich Park ,you cannot marvel at its architecture. So I was very fortunate, to book a tour of one of the magnificent Wren Dome tours, and he is what we uncovered on this October day. We arrived at Greenwich train station and made our way through Greenwich town centre as it was Saturday the town was the usual hustle and bustle as you expected, we passed the famous tea clipper the Cutty Sark, we watched some Morris dancing see my picture below was quite a sight, before making our way to the Painted Hall visitor centre to check in, once we had we walked under the undercroft ,up the stairs to the chapel, we waited for our tour to start, we had to wait as the chapel was been used for a wedding which again was a bonus. After a few moments our tour guide Antonio and Janice arrived, this tour is very new so you can only go in groups of 6 people just to let you know. We then ascended up a flight of spiral stairs to different parts of the Dome, the climbing of the Dome was to celebrate the 300 year anniversary of Sir Christopher Wren Death in 1723, he lived until he died at the age 90, the feet was more as he was the only man to design a major cathedral and live to see it completed, other famous designs are the impressive St Paul’s Cathedral and Royal Hospital in Chelsea So moving on with the tour, we climbed stairs, and took loads of pictures of the exceptional views, there are some pictures below but I did take a few. Our guides went through loads of historical information and also there were ancient Graffiti hidden inside parts of the Dome Wooden infrastructure. After 45 minutes we made our decent back to where we had started the tour, finally your ticket does include a look around the impressive Painted Hall so before you leave I suggest you give it a visit. So in summary, this Wren Masterpiece just had to be visited on your bucket list, so well Dome Sir Christopher.

top_reviews.title: Lots of History
top_reviews.review: Walking around the Old Royal Naval College offers a captivating blend of royal history and cinematic charm. As you explore its grounds, you're immersed in centuries of maritime heritage and architectural splendour. Built as a royal palace for King Henry VIII in the 16th century, the site later became a naval hospital for Seamen. In the 19th century, the Hospital moved to a new location, and the site was repurposed as the Royal Naval College. It served this purpose until 1998, when the college closed, and the site was redeveloped into a cultural educational centre. What made the experience even more special was discovering the college's connection to the world of cinema. As a movie buff, it was a thrill to realize that these historic surroundings had served as a backdrop for some of my favourite films, including Thor: The Dark World. Walking in the footsteps of beloved characters and exploring the same courtyards and corridors seen on screen was an unforgettable experience, adding an extra layer of magic to my visit.

top_reviews.title: A unique tour and view from the Dome
top_reviews.review: The Secret Dome Tour So pleased that this tour has continued this year. Initially was available last year to acknowledge 300 years since the death of Christopher Wren. Unfortunately all available tours (limited availability ) sold out quickly . Therefore was really pleased to get an opportunity to book - limited tours with only 6 people per tour. The ascent to the top is via stone and wooden stairs, in some places very narrow, but safety measures are covered re description of the tour and what is required. Good footwear is essential. Plus there are two Members that cover the tour. Isobelle was our guide, who is a volunteer and clearly very passionate about the tour . She has a vast knowledge base about the tour and its history. Hamish was the other staff member at rear to ensure no missteps and safety if the group. We were lucky only 2 in our group, although it is usually fully booked. There were 3 levels and opportunities to ask questions and take photos. It is expensive but it is an opportunity to go in the Dome and have a very unique experience and view from the Dome. I would definitely recommend and really enjoyed it. Plus you get a gift bag at the end of the tour and it covers other tours ie painted Hall and can be upgraded online to cover another visit to the Royal Naval College tours ( although this does not cover Dome Tour).

top_reviews.title: An underrated London ‘must see’
top_reviews.review: One of the most underrated London experiences with a rich and beautiful history underpinning the entire site. Absolutely beautiful. Should you get the opportunity track down a tour guide called Jim Morrison.,a gentleman and a man of boundless enthusiasm and knowledge.

top_reviews.title: Vertiginous views!
top_reviews.review: What a wonderful, engaging, enlightening experience. The Secret Dome tour is well worth squeezing into the narrow, spiral steps for. A privilege to gain access to such fascinating spaces & terrific views. We learned so much about the history & architecture from superb guide, Mike. 🌟

top_reviews.title: Go to the Painted Hall
top_reviews.review: We bought our tickets so that we could see the Painted Hall, which was exquisite with its grand paintings. It is where Nelson's body was place for viewing after his death at Trafalgar. We did our own self-guided tour, reading the plaques inside. The college is made up of large buildings designed by Christopher Wren and sits on the banks of the Thames in Greenwich.

top_reviews.title: Tremendous
top_reviews.review: Even reading about its history and that of the site is impressive. Originally a Palace stood here that fell into dereliction during the Civil War and was demolished in 1694. Then arose the great buildings we admire today. First as the Royal Hospital for Seamen; it ceased operations as a Hospital in 1869. Just 4 years later it was converted to a Naval College. Within are great sights, particularly the exquisite Painted Hall but also the lovely Chapel of St Peter and St Paul. It was certainly atmospheric walking along the impressive undercrofts of which there are a number. Including the Queen Mary one. After all that, a fine Café is open for replenishment and refreshments.

top_reviews.title: Fantastic secret dome tour by Bob & Antonio
top_reviews.review: We were very impressed by both the building and heritage itself, but also how friendly and knowledgeable all the staff were. We did a history tour followed by the secret dome tour. Both were great but the secret dome tour has to be the highlight. Thank you Bob & Antonio for providing a fantastic experience. The painted hall and chapel are stunning

name: Regent's Park
description: Originally a royal hunting ground, this scenic park is a popular recreation area offering an artificial lake, tennis courts, cricket ground, children's playgrounds and the London Zoo, which lies on the north side of the park.
address: Outer Cir, London NW1 4NR England

top_reviews.title: Relaxing time in a very hectic City
top_reviews.review: 2 autumn mornings spent walking through these gardens in one of the Royal Parks. They are a delight. Beautifully and interestingly laid out, maintained to an exceptional standard and provide some peaceful time in an exceptionally loud, busy city. It’s remarkable how these parks can be maintained with Govt funding yet such funding is not available elsewhere in the UK. They are the Royal Parks and as such should be available to ALL UK citizens. It is a serious deficiency that these parks are only available in and around London.

top_reviews.title: Large oasis
top_reviews.review: This large park is always worth a visit because it changes every season. There is lots to see and it may be that a visitor may need to focus in on one or two areas rather than try to see it all. I entered from the Camden side and came out at the Marylebone side. I saw lots but it took a lot of steps. Lots of paths to follow, water features, flower gardens, trees and lots more. If you get the season right, Queen Mary's Rose Garden is a delight. The roses were just coming out when I visited in mid /late May. Very nice.

top_reviews.title: Greenery
top_reviews.review: Originally part of the Forest of Middlesex and hunting ground for King Henry VIII, the Regent’s Park has been named after the Prince Regent (who later became King George IV). For a runner like me, this has been turned into a running trail in the morning. You won't get lost, even if the park is huge. Take break to watch squirrels if you are tired. Or else, find a cup of coffee from the cafeteria.

top_reviews.title: Gorgeous Royal Park in central London
top_reviews.review: One of the joys of attending Regents University is walking through Regents Parks to get to class in different seasons. I also enjoy having lunch in one of the park cafes and discovering different floral arrangements, enjoying the bare trees or green foliage and watching ducks on the ornamental lake. During this visit in March it was mostly tree skeletons on view just before spring arrives. Regent’s Park is surrounded by stunning Regency architecture. There is also a zoo, aviary, children’s playground and allotments. In the spring and summer, look out open air plays or enjoy picnics on Primrose Hill.

top_reviews.title: An Oasis of Calm in London
top_reviews.review: I used Regents Park the previous day to walk to and from the Zoo, but the weather was horrendous. I walked back to the park the next morning after breakfast on a Sunday morning quite early, and apart from dog walkers and joggers it was very quiet. As you would expect from a Royal Park, the area is very well laid out with ornamental fountains, follies and lots of plants and trees. It was so peaceful, I felt like I was in the countryside as opposed to the centre of London. Definitely worth a visit, but I only stayed there a short while as I had a flight to catch.

top_reviews.title: 自然的避风港——摄政公园
top_reviews.review: 摄政公园是伦敦市中心的一片绿洲，以其宽阔的草坪、湖泊和丰富的植物而闻名。这里是市民休闲放松、享受自然的理想场所。 Regent's Park is an oasis in the heart of London, known for its wide lawns, lakes, and diverse plant life. It is an ideal place for residents to relax and enjoy nature. Enter RC777E on trainpal and you get a 20% discount on your train ticket.

name: Covent Garden
description: Filled with restaurants, bars, markets and boutiques, London's premier tourist center offers fabulous shopping by day, and the destination of theatergoers and patrons of the Royal Opera House by night.
category: Points of Interest & Landmarks Flea & Street Markets
address: Covent Garden, London WC2E 9DD England

top_reviews.title: Tourist magnet ...
top_reviews.review: When visiting London, we always come back to this well kept "market & entertainment" spot. Just walking around, doing some real or window shopping, stopping in a café/on a terrace, watching some street artists ... It's a "must visit" for plenty of fellow tourists, but not overcrowded ... it's clean&safe.

top_reviews.title: Covenent
top_reviews.review: One trip to Covent gardens is a must while visiting London. This time I had to shop from Hobbs and Charlotte tillbury over there and thats what I did. Its a touristy place no doubt . Later we took a stroll towards Oxford street.

top_reviews.title: Early birthday trip to London
top_reviews.review: Well after a ride on a busy tube with a number of changes ended up here at Covent Garden . Just lovely and well worth the journey ! Had a lovely biscuit from the famous bens cookies and a drink in the punch and Judy had to be done !! Had a lovely walk around the numerous small shops and the street entertainment was outstanding loved Charlie chaplain !! This place had a lovely vibe to it and could have spent hours more there if hadn’t had to rush back for theatre show xx well worth a visit x couldn’t resist telling the gorilla I was a monkey hanger the look on his face !! 😀

top_reviews.title: Short's Garden Events - Beware of the Power of Your Beauty
top_reviews.review: Beauty will always exist from within us all. All of us have the accessibilities to make beauty feel like something from within the soul searching for paths to explore identities. The nouveau of beauty are exemplar in living well and living for your individualistic self-worth. The panel consisted of Sharon Lloyd, Joseph Harwood and Millie Flemington - Clare. Each panellist had a powerful orality to discuss the theme of beauty that should be both inclusive and advocacy on contemporary advancements in what is considered as beautiful. Each participant on the panel had an added value to the conversation. The conversation had rhizomatic qualities to adding rooted thoughts that cannot stop evolving and growing. Beauty continues to be an aestheticism without boundaries. Non linear dialogues exist in the mainstream frameworks have to be acknowledged thus to place emphasis on the endless possibilities that come from engaging with the beauty industry. Largest minority in the world are individuals who could become disabled because life happens to us all. The big companies should not be marginalised and silence to deny their voices to be constructive parts of beauty narratives in the realms of societal advancements. Being adaptable and learning new skills is the best remedy to articulate who you are in such a fluid society. This life lesson is applicable to a plethora of situations and circumstances. It is vital to discuss the concept of beauty should be relatable to narratives explored across the ages. Thus the means of beauty could be something more and know they should aim for something more. N.B. The event held was a concise and confident way to shape the beauty industry on behalf of the British Beauty Week 2023.

top_reviews.title: Fantastic Atmosphere - Awesome Shops
top_reviews.review: This was just fantastic - they had all the Christmas decorations up and the atmosphere was buzzing. We popped in and out of shops, although the one I was looking forward to visiting I couldn't as it was up 3 flights of stairs and my wonky legs would not take it. I enjoyed the ambience of the area and especially the four-piece string ensemble which we observed from the upper area. We enjoyed them so much, that when one of the group came around with CDs we made a purchase. I felt they really made Covent Garden come alive. There are so many great shops to browse, truly something for everyone. We didn't find it too crowded and were able to explore the area easily. A tip I can give you is to watch where you are walking if you do have "Wonky Legs" as the flooring can go from flat paving to cobbled.

top_reviews.title: Top Notch experience
top_reviews.review: Absolutely amazing hotel and such a beautiful, lively, vibrant, thriving location. Stacey in the hotel is such an affable, gregarious, benevolent and charming host. She is such an asset to Travelodge @ Covent Garden. I will certainly be returning again in the future. 😇😊😁

top_reviews.title: A nice place to visit for history and browsing shops.
top_reviews.review: An interesting place to visit and much improved over the years. Although we went on a very cold Tuesday most of the shops were open. Would be better at a weekend I am sure. Would recommend going on a walking tour for the history. Did feel that £1.50 to use the public loos was very expensive - having said that they were spotless.

top_reviews.title: A lively cultural hotspot
top_reviews.review: Covent Garden London is a lively cultural hotspot with something for everyone! From the bustling markets to the street performers, it's the perfect place to explore and experience the city's culture. The atmosphere is always lively, and the shops are full of unique finds. Whether you're looking for a souvenir or a quick bite, Covent Garden has it all!

top_reviews.title: Covent Garden
top_reviews.review: We too a trip to Covent Garden. We wanted to visit the shops and the market stalls. See what was in the form of street entertainment. Maybe see if there was something interesting to eat or drink. We ended up doing more browsing than shopping.

top_reviews.title: Good and interesting
top_reviews.review: This is a great place to find your winter clothes with quality and great prices. You can find a cashmere winter coat for $99.00. They also have a lot of vintage item of all kind. It is a very interesting place to visit. The transportation museum is near by and it is surrounded by high end restaurants. It’s a wonderful place to spent your day .

name: Lord's Cricket Ground
description: Lord's Cricket Ground is known as the Home of Cricket and is owned by Marylebone Cricket Club - better known, throughout the cricketing world, as MCC. Founded in 1787, MCC is the world's most famous cricket club.
address: St John's Wood Rd., London NW8 8QN England

top_reviews.title: Well worth the Fee
top_reviews.review: A very enjoyable tour round Lords. Our guide, Jeff, was full of information, very friendly and humorous. The tour takes just over 90 minutes but you go everywhere you want to, changing room, long room, media centre etc. The tour was thoroughly enjoyable and well worth the £30pp we paid - a tour even non cricket lovers I think would also enjoy. We also happened to bump into ex-England cricketer Mike Gatting which was an added bonus

top_reviews.title: Lords - Tour
top_reviews.review: I bought this your for my 14 year old son who is cricket daft. He was so excited and loved every second of the experience. We were lucky enough to get assigned Jeff as our guide, Jeff was so passionate about everything to do with lords and what a credit to the team he is. Thank you Jeff for your your, knowledge and humour throughout. We loved every second. Louise and matthew from Sunderland

top_reviews.title: A Day to Cherish Forever
top_reviews.review: It was an emotional and unique experience for us - a journey by time machine way back to 1983 when Kapil Dev had created history on this very ground. Within a span of two hours, our tour guide, an extremely amiable and pleasant personality, covered the history of the place and touched upon the memorable moments created at Lords. It was an experience beyond dreams when we walked through the corridors and sat in the dressing rooms which have been frequented by stalwarts. Adequate time was given to take photos at different venues to relive the past and cherish the present. As we scanned through the names of players drafted for their remarkable performance(s) at Lords, we went through a roller coaster of emotions and realised how fortunate we were to be a part of this immersive experience. The tour ended with the buying of souvenirs, clinging onto the golden memories.

top_reviews.title: Home of cricket
top_reviews.review: The Lords tour is a must do for any cricket fan. Tour starts in museum which is full of amazing cricket history and the crown jewel The Ashes urn. Then you are guided to different parts of the ground including dressing rooms , long room, media section and many different views of this iconic sporting venue. Tour guides Tom and Jay were amazing and managed to make my non cricket fan wife have a great experience. Brilliant tour.

top_reviews.title: A MUST do for Cricket Lovers passing through London
top_reviews.review: A rare glimpse of a Special World! Our Lords Tour Guide loved his job and knew his Cricket History really really well ! Some great stories, told with passion and great humour while walking around the hallowed turf

top_reviews.title: Bob and Brenda make for a fantastic tour
top_reviews.review: Took this tour with my wife on February 28th with Bob as our guide. The tour surpassed all expectations, Bob's passion for cricket is infectious and he shared countless facts and stories that made the whole experience an engaging and informative. This is a can't-miss tour for anyone who loves sports, regardless of the prior knowledge level of cricket.

top_reviews.title: Great guided tour
top_reviews.review: Recently did a guided tour of the ground with Tony as the guide. He was just superb. Very informative and allowed people time to take images. He was an absolute star. You will see the museum, the long room, both changing rooms, grandstand and media area. I didn't realise the pitch was so small! Well worth a visit.

top_reviews.title: A cricket lover’s dream
top_reviews.review: What more can I say other than this is an experience that, if you are a cricket lover, you cannot miss. Thank you in particular to our tour guides, John and Brenda, who were friendly, informative and funny! A spectacular ground, great museum and the art collection is something special.

top_reviews.title: If you love cricket you will Love this tour.
top_reviews.review: This was brought for me as a Christmas present, we had tickets for the guided tour (Gladstone Small) and a tour guide (an Australian lady (forgot her name which is a shame)) with lunch in the players dinning room, We started in the museum and Gladstone turned up at 1030 and talked through some of the exhibits we then toured half of the ground including the players dressing rooms committee room (where Douglas Jardine presented the ashes to the committee after the famous Bodyline series) and the world famous Long Room Both our tour guides were very informative with Gladstone adding lots of funny story's of his life playing for England and his time at lords. The dinning room experience was great the food to die for, again some funny story's from the catering manager and what she has to deal with, with the demanding players. Finally a visit to the media centre again very informative. I would say overall all the staff were very friendly and knowledgeable and although not cheep as a cricket lover was a magical experience and one of the best days out I have ever had

top_reviews.title: A must do for any cricket fan
top_reviews.review: Recently did the tour of Lords which was fantastic. Jamie was our guide and he was exceptionally knowledgeable and likeable chap. As an Australian there was a lot of banter about the recent Ashes tour and certain events of the Long Room. To visit the Long Room, the dressing room and balconies was just amazing. Seeing the original Ashes and other memorabilia in the museum was fantastic, very limited displays of the Women’s game though. If you aren’t lucky enough to catch a game here, this is a must do for any cricket fan passing through London

name: The London Bridge Experience
description: The London Bridge Experience, crowned ‘Best Guided Tour’ & London Tombs, crowned ‘Top Horror Attraction in the World!’ is a two-part immersive show, bringing together history and horror, education and fun. Guests laugh, scream and cheer their way through 2,000 years of history during the London Bridge Experience, then enter the vaults of the bridge [if they dare], known as London Tombs, which is a psychological scare-maze themed upon everyone's worse fears! Winner of the UK’s scariest attraction for 13 years, the Tombs part of the show is not for the faint hearted!
address: 2-4 Tooley Street The Rennie Vaults, London SE1 2PF England

top_reviews.title: A great place to visit!
top_reviews.review: A little hard to find but once in a great experience! Front of house pleasantly welcome you and pass you on to the tour guide who meets you at the bottom of a dark stairwell! A history of the bridge with actors to the final maze! Take it if you dare! A great laugh, some very dark bits with actors to scare you through your journey. Would definitely recommend a visit if in town!

top_reviews.title: Fun!
top_reviews.review: First off, thumbs up 👍🏻 to the extremely amazing customer service provided at The London Bridge Experience! Everyone there was very friendly, warm, inviting and helpful, even though the experience was meant to be scary. Which it was when you entered the nearly completely dark cellar and started the journey and tour. Even on the tour staff were also funny and put all effort into sticking to their characters. It was a very enjoyable experience. Unfortunately photography wasn't allowed. So in order to know what goes on down there, you'd just need to join the tour and experience it on your own. Definitely not for people with heart issues, but a should do with couples, friends and families with older children.

top_reviews.title: Zombie for a day experience!
top_reviews.review: My husband knows I'm still on a mission to find as many weird & wonderful experiences as I can...and this Christmas present definitely fit the bill! Not really knowing what to expect, we were first whisked off underground on the London Bridge experience - scary!!! - and after recovering from that, we were met by the incredibly accommodating Harry, who took us off to his subterranean dressing room to meet the cast! ( very cool) After our zombie make-up tutorial and costume change we had an incredible 3 course lunch in the restaurant above, and then Harry (our zombie leader) took us off to prepare us for scaring the general public 😁 A fantastic day where we got even more than we bargained for and it was worth every single penny! Harry was a superb guide and we had more fun than we've had in quite a while 😄👍👍👍

top_reviews.title: Made to feel welcome and part of the experience!
top_reviews.review: For a family experience, this is great fun and super cost effective too. The staff couldn’t make you feel more welcome and for anyone nervous or needing adjustments they are sensitive and couldn’t do enough. In fact, the great staff really made the day. There is a genuinely good balance of historical fact that gives the tour relevance (we’re not talking A level revision territory, just some useful insight into how long the bridge has been there and it’s part in London’s broader history). It’s brought to life through an immersive experience that is a great add on to a trip to the area and definitely worth a go. Genuinely this is better than the London Dungeon which just felt impersonal, expensive and put us off experiences like this about five years ago and just wasn’t good if anyone in your party needs adjustments. This is not something we normally would have done and I am so glad we did. Thanks all at the London Bridge Experience!

top_reviews.title: Not bad but over priced
top_reviews.review: It was okay and fun. I have nothing bad to say about this place, the actors were good and it's fun. The only thing I will say is that there is 0 point going here and also going to London dungeons. London Dungeons actors, stories, and whole general experience is far far superior and much more immersive. At similar prices I just don't see why you'd need to do both. Also one slight issue in my opinion is, for the jump scare part at the end they make you go in a line with your hand placed on the person in front of you 's back. Now this is clearly for safety as it is very dark and I totally understand the need for this but if you are not in the front third of the line then the jump scare is absolutely pointless as you know exactly when it is coming because you hear the others scream.

name: The Great Christmas Feast
description: The Lost Estate’s Iconic Festive Experience celebrates five sold-out years and an all-new venue Enter the winding, starlit streets of Victorian London. Lose yourself in the magic of Dickens' timeless classic 'A Christmas Carol'. Indulge in a Yuletide Feast while you watch. The Great Christmas Feast is Back
address: 9 Beaumont Avenue The Lost Estate, London W14 9LP England

top_reviews.title: Best Christmas activitiy EVER
top_reviews.review: I had the most amazing time ever - the food was absolutely delicious, it really felt like Christmas inside with the incredible set as well as the insane acting by Alex Phelps and the musicians were equally as phenomenal. I honestly couldn’t knock it, I would go as far to say it has been my favourite immersive experience in London so far, and I’ve been to A LOT! Cannot wait for what The Lost Estate has in store next 10/10!

top_reviews.title: Amazing experience
top_reviews.review: I loved every single bit of the experience. Starting from the VIP entrance, to the food and performance! Well spent money! I definitely recommend and I would also go back any time to the next attraction! You guys rock

top_reviews.title: A Spectacular Blend of Flavour and Performance!
top_reviews.review: I Absolutely loved every moment – the food was utterly delicious and the set was outstanding. The phenomenal acting added to the overall brilliance, complemented perfectly by the equally exceptional musicians. A Truly Unforgettable Experience.

top_reviews.title: Fantastic evening
top_reviews.review: Fantastic evening, thank you to all involved. Staff at the door and serving were so kind and welcoming, the food was a great experience and the acting and music were wonderful. The dining area/staging is so beautiful, and we loved the glowing candlelight effect.

top_reviews.title: Incredible experience
top_reviews.review: The food was incredible, and so were the drinks..I didn’t know what a ‘Smoking Bishop’ was ..now I’ll forever be in search of another one. The lighting was stunning, the atmosphere was exciting. It was an incredible huge-hearted event and it warmed the soul- Thank you !

top_reviews.title: A Wonderland for the imagination, the senses…and the belly!
top_reviews.review: I have never witnessed a more immersive, emotional and more perfect a performance from both a theatrical and musical perspective. Coupled with exquisite foods, based on the Dickensian themed meals, and delicious drinks. It was a sensory wonderland! From the moment we walked in, we genuinely were transported to the past. I still cannot explain or describe just how magical this experience was. The waiting staff were incredible, so accommodating and the taller lady at the doorway to the seating area was marvellous! The music was utter perfection! The arrangements were so delicately composed to create such poignant dissonance while still reserving the whisper of familiarity in the carols melody. Alex Phelps is a wonder to behold. Never have I seen anything or anyone in all my time in media, who captures your soul and imagination so effortlessly. One of the last true story tellers and without doubt one of the finest actors of our time. I congratulate all of you on creating magic and a memory that will live with me forever. Thank you!

top_reviews.title: The greatest show!
top_reviews.review: The whole event was just amazing! So much talent definitely a must! if anyone was thinking about going! You will regret it if you don’t!! The show, the food, Worth every penny! I’m already looking forward to the next event

top_reviews.title: Magical
top_reviews.review: What a fantastic experience! From the moment we entered the room we were absolutely wowed by the spectacular scenography and lighting. The food and cocktails were delicious and the acting and music was superb! Couldn’t fault anything, definitely worth going!

top_reviews.title: A Spectacular immersive experience
top_reviews.review: An immersive night of Theater , music , cocktails, friends and memories made. We had so much and enjoyed this Unique way of enjoying theater but also having a delicious meal. We got lost in Dickinsons world.

top_reviews.title: Best night ever!
top_reviews.review: I cannot recommend this event enough. It was absolutely fabulous. My husband and I were spellbound the entire evening. Music, acting, setting, production - all incredible. The food was fantastic and our only criticism was that there weren't enough potatoes to accompany the delicious duck leg. Would go again in a heartbeat.

name: Horizon 22
description: London's Highest Free Viewing Platform
address: 22 Bishopsgate, London EC2N 4BQ England

top_reviews.title: Accomplished
top_reviews.review: A free viewing gallery here was mandatory, as were others, but it's the attitude to that requirement which matters. As well as the spectacular views the visitor here sees the owners have seized the moment rather than begrudgingly accepted it. Go. It's glorious. Minimalist, expansive, breathtaking. The coffee is expensive but good (and they'll let you sit by a window while drinking it). Best of all you can see all your old favourites (and won't have to see the one you're on because it ain't a looker). It's not only higher than The View from you-know-what, it's better as an experience than it.

top_reviews.title: Free panoramic London views
top_reviews.review: Wow! Stunning views. Plenty of space to roam around. Floor to ceiling windows give extensive panoramic views. Simon, team leader very knowledgeable. All staff friendly and welcoming. There's no rushing you through so that more people can enter. There are some seats near kiosk where you can purchase refreshments. A few more further round would be welcome. Be aware you enter on one side of building and exit the other. We were lucky enough to get a walk in ticket. If you're in the area it's worth asking if there are any tickets available, unlikely at weekends.

top_reviews.title: Up above the skygarden and shard you'll find Horizon 22
top_reviews.review: I like the effect of the vast open space but only having 3 or 4 tables by the coffee spot is not enough. A few more options to sit down would be good. My friend had a bad knee and she had nowhere to rest. The staff are 5 star, so friendly and knowledgeable about the city and, of course, the views are stellar!

top_reviews.title: Bird’s eye view!
top_reviews.review: This is London’s newest viewing platform on the 58th floor. We were lucky enough to visit on a clear day so the views were amazing. The Shard was below us as was St. Paul’s, the Tower of London and the London eye. As it’s only recently opened there is a small temporary cafe with plans to build a permanent one. Lots of staff around to direct you and answer questions.

top_reviews.title: Looking down on the Shard
top_reviews.review: The views over London were spectacular. Although we had not previously booked, they were able to fit us in as a 'walk-in half an hour later. I would recommend prior booking if it's likely to be busy e.g. school holidays. Unbelievably in this current economic climate a visit is actually free. There were lots of cheery helpful staff to guide you through the building. Although the viewing gallery is 58 floors up the lift didn't feel like it. There was a small coffee bar in the viewing gallery.

top_reviews.title: Fabulous.
top_reviews.review: I booked on the day bookings opened (now fully booked until mid December). Sailed smoothly up to the 58th Floor where the views are spectacular. It was a sunnyish morning but quite bright and hazy. Only downside were the reflections from the windows which made photos a little challenging. Staff were lovely and a special thanks to Simon, a team leader, who very kindly took a couple of photos of me. There is a small hot drinks stall and a couple of tables and chairs. Decent coffee and not too expensive. Overall a great place and it’s free!

top_reviews.title: Awesome views of London
top_reviews.review: Visited in October 2023 during a weekday. Accessing the event was straight-forward and staff (reception, security and lift wardens) were friendly and helpful. There were definitely no crowds relative to those, for example, at the sky garden in the walkie talkie building or the Shard. Views of London are impressive and, in my opinion, more so than those experienced from the Shard. As this is an in-door experience, the only downside is the level of glare from the window and associated shadows which is something to bear in mind when taking photos here. Worth booking tickets in advance as these sell out very quickly. Overall, the views were memorable and definitely worth the visit.

top_reviews.title: We would happily go back again
top_reviews.review: A very enjoyable experience. Friendly and helpful staff. Not crowded so easy to walk around for spectacular views. Tea and coffee from the small kiosk was very welcome. Well worth the patience needed to get tickets.

top_reviews.title: Great Views, No Queues
top_reviews.review: We've done the Sky Garden a few times and stayed in the Shard. All have great views, but this is so much higher. We visited during half term and it was quiet, which meant there was no scrum for the windows. We got some great photos, but perhaps some glare coating would've been nice to prevent so much reflection. The kids had a great time too. We would definitely come again. Hopefully there'd be some comfy seats and a bar next time.

top_reviews.title: Try a clear day or twighlight
top_reviews.review: I see this place on social media and really wanted to see it. I love tall buildings and taking photos. I expected to pay for such an opportunity but when I went on line it was free. Just book a slot and you're in. The staff were amazing. Very friendly, very helpful and shared tips for enjoying the view and taking photos. There is a small coffee stall. No gift shop and you are not expected to be sold anything. How many places can say that. It was spacious and modern. There are toilets and as a wheelchair user it is completely easy to access al areas.

name: National Maritime Museum
description: Experience the world's largest maritime museum, filled with inspirational stories of exploration and endeavour at sea and packed to the gunwales with intriguing objects and fascinating galleries. See the uniform Nelson wore at the Battle of Trafalgar, steer a ship into port and fire at pesky pirates.
address: Romney Rd, London SE10 9NF England

top_reviews.title: Ahoy! and museum visit
top_reviews.review: Visited the Ahoy! soft play area and the museum, the latter we have done quite some times. The soft play area is part of a trend of museums venturing into new revenue streams, by offering pre booked soft play sessions. The play area was okay, but not they special. Not that busy at the moment we visited (on a Sunday morning). In all honesty, I do have mixed feelings about that. 40 minutes of play is not that much and then you need to tell your children they need to leave. Let’s say that needed some convincing. We did visit some other galleries, but having been here before meant that we did not hang any must sees on our list.

top_reviews.title: Nice museum for nautical history and entertainment
top_reviews.review: A nice free museum when visiting Greenwich. A love of nautical adventure and history is essential to benefit from the museum. The staff are very friendly and helpful to visitors. The museum is not too large and clearly laid out. There are various play areas for children. There is a cafe and plenty of seats available to take a break. It has a family-friendly feel and takes around an hour to visit at a quick pace. There are some good historical sections, for those wishing to learn more about maritime history. It is good for a quick visit and helpful to keep the little ones entertained for a while.

top_reviews.title: Really interesting museum. Lots to see and do.
top_reviews.review: Really interesting museum. Lots to see and do. There is no charge for entry. The displays are arranged into sections dealing with the technology in the different periods of time. There are various free talks available. We listened to a talk by Rosalind on "Ghost Ships" which was very enlightening. Even if you are not an enthusiastic museum visitor, with the Cutty Sark located nearby, there is no problem filling in a complete day at this location.

top_reviews.title: Sea Shanty Tour was excellent
top_reviews.review: My wife and I took her parents to the Greenwich Park and were going to visit the Observatory at first, but went to the Maritime museum instead. It is free (unlike the Observatory, that is £18 per person). The museum staff were very welcoming and told us about the Sea Shanty tour about to start shortly after our arrival. The Shanty tour was fantastic. Shout out to Mark B who presented it. It was very information reach, interesting. Last, but not least, we got to sing along one of the shanties. Lots of fun. Highly recommend.

top_reviews.title: Tour with Tessa
top_reviews.review: We took a tour led by Tessa, and it was fantastic. She did a wonderful job of showing us highlights of the museum, since the museum has over 2 million artifacts. Her knowledge was very impressive. The tour included headphones so everyone could hear (there were an unusual number of school children there the day we visited, so it got quite loud at times). We were very impressed with the museum and the tour, and hope to return to see more of the exhibits

top_reviews.title: Great Museum, Plenty to see
top_reviews.review: A great Free museum with plenty of exhibits - you could spend all day. Very interesting with a few integrative items as well as a special are for the kids. Staff very friendly, helpful & able to answer questions. Was well maintained and kept clean.

top_reviews.title: Treasure tour with Suzy
top_reviews.review: Treasure tour with Suzy was absolutely amaizing. We have learnt so many interesting facts and info about exhibits , Capitan Cook, Nelson and Arctic and Antractic expeditions. I have taken a tour with very mature and eager to learn 4 y.o. He loved it. Thank you Suzy!!! Felix loved war fighting ships and paintings of battles. Very informative.

top_reviews.title: Interesting exhibits and very family friendly
top_reviews.review: Great family friendly museum with an outdoor play area that kept all the 4 year olds I went with and one 7 year old happily busy for a while. Also had fun pushing boats around the Great Map. In the exhibits lots of interesting things to look at and learn about and kid friendly interactive stuff. I would actually like to come back on my own to read a bit more but kids rather raced through some of the galleries. Also impressed by how inclusive the museum is with events promoted targeting different families that maybe aren't always actively marketed too in this type of space. Finished off in the soft play which was a good end to our day out and the staff there were great, friendly and helpful - especially when one of the kids had a minor accident. Loved the gift shops too, some great displays and loads of stuff I was tempted to buy books. toys, etc. The only negative thing is how far it is from where we live otherwise would visit more often!

top_reviews.title: The Incredible Shanty Man!
top_reviews.review: Had an amazing time, and especially enjoyed the Trafalgar and Nelson exhibits. However, the best part of the visit was the Sea Shanty talk by Mark! His enthusiasm for the subject was infectious and singing a shanty with the group was so much fun. He made the whole experience so incredibly interesting and engaging! If you’re visiting the museum, definitely attend his talk. We had a fantastic time.

top_reviews.title: A Brilliant Day Out for Little Outlay
top_reviews.review: A brilliant place to go for a day's entertainment. All ages are catered for and with free admission and ridiculously low-cost guided tours, it's accessible for all pockets. The cafe is reasonable too, and the staff make it an enjoyable visit. All in all it's a 10/10 from me.

name: The Magic Circle Theatre
description: The Magic Circle Headquarters is home to the world's premier magical society, The Magic Circle. It also houses a theatre, museum and entertainment space. We regularly hold events and open days for the public including History and Mystery at The Magic Circle, At Home with The Magic Circle, Close-up at The Magic Circle, Monday Morning Magic and The Magic Circle Christmas Show. Admission to these events is by advance booking only via our website. The nearest tube stations are Euston Square (2 min walk) and Warren Street (5 minute walk) Note The Magic Circle HQ is not open for casual visits.
address: 12 Stephenson Way Centre For The Magic Arts, London NW1 2HD England

top_reviews.title: Unique and magical
top_reviews.review: This is the inner sanctity for magicians but it is in a rather non-descript building behind Euston Station. There is an amazing circular staircase and museum. The latter contains information and exhibits from well known historical magicians. There is also a small bar but strangely the rooms we saw were devoid of windows. The highlight was an intimate show performed by 4 separate and single magicians and this was exceptional with audience involvement. Overall somewhere to visit if you are able.

top_reviews.title: Wonderfully skillful close-up magic tricks
top_reviews.review: We went to a close-up magic evening. It's a very intimate space. Just a few dozen audience members, and four separate magicians performing close-up magic just beyond arms reach. Each magician was really engaging and brought their own style and skill to the show. It's such a lovely atmosphere, the magicians clearly love performing as they stay in the bar after the main show, ready to chat and continue to show even more tricks to those that are interested. I highly recommend it.

top_reviews.title: Halloween Show and Spirits Cabinet 2023
top_reviews.review: The 2023 Halloween Show was okay: a charming hosts, a couple of magicians, a juggling artist. Nothing to write home about, though, especially since the only female in the programme was scantily dressed and danced around in an LED butterfly costume after appearing magic-assistant-like from another magician's trick, not performing any magic herself. In general, the entire evening might have benefited from a woman's perspective, but the Magic Circle did not seem to have left its patriarchal past in the past. The bar sold reasonably priced cocktails that were light on alcohol and that you could not take into the theatre. This I actually found refreshing, but telling the audience that would have been nice, especially since the seats had not been allocated. Before the performance or in the interval you could visit the museum - a room with famous magician's items and you even got a guide explaining three things to the assembled crowd. The seance with a Victorian inspired Spirits' Cabinet was too clownish for my taste, but a nice nod to the Halloween occasion. All in all, an evening to explore the famous magicians' headquarters and the weird fraternity feeling it projects, but a bit too expensive for a lack of wowing tricks or names.

top_reviews.title: Blew my expectations away.
top_reviews.review: I love magic, and was excited to see this show. However it was so much better than even I expected. All the magicians were brilliant - both as comedians and magicians. I would highly recommend, and I can't wait to go back again.

top_reviews.title: Epic.
top_reviews.review: Epic - four world class, close up magicians in a fascinating and interesting setting - brain stretching performances, packed with charm, full of mystery and each different. A great bar and a friendly welcoming vibe. Recommended. Go and be amazed!

top_reviews.title: Really fun
top_reviews.review: Went to the Christmas show which was excellent. The magic was of course impressive, but more than that, the whole experience was so friendly and good natured, we felt like guests invited to a private party more than spectators. I took two rather grumpy/sceptical guests, one old one young, but they actually both had a great time for once. Go as soon as doors open: there is an atmospheric private museum with some interesting stuff including an original copy of a book on witchcraft that dates from medieval times, Tommy Cooper’s fez, etc, and also there is a bar and magicians wandering around doing tricks. There was a lady upstairs making free silhouettes of people, I wish I’d realised earlier that she was there!

top_reviews.title: And now for something different
top_reviews.review: Went to the Xmas show. The show itself was very well compèred by Harry. The magic was very good and even if it was nothing too groundbreaking. The view wasn’t the best at the back of the theatre but just about adequate. The museum is small but a nice add on. Tucked away on a backstreet and with a small bar inside, it makes for an unusual evening’s entertainment.

top_reviews.title: Extraordinary magic show
top_reviews.review: Excellent mind boggling magic! All the magicians were hilarious, genuine magic and showmanship! Well worth the evening entertainment and highly recommend. We will be going again as they keep changing the shows and magic. 100% recommend it for all.

top_reviews.title: Sod the panto, come here.
top_reviews.review: Highlight of our Christmas! Managed to get hold of tickets for the last night of their Christmas show, and I am so glad we did as it was utterly brilliant! As part of the show you can be shown round the museum, which had some “really cool things in” said my teen son (high praise indeed) and our guide was very entertaining in his explanations of the “really cool things” (no spoilers here)…. “Sod the panto, come here” is now our Christmas motto, but don’t tell everyone or we won’t all get tickets…

top_reviews.title: Great evening, will definitely return
top_reviews.review: Fantastic evening with my wife and 11 year old son. Four intimate shows with different magicians, and all were excellent. They also took time to allow my son to perform his card tricks in the interval as well as perform additional tricks in the bar afterwards. Will definitely return

name: The Courtauld Gallery
description: The Courtauld Gallery is home to one of the world’s great art collections, located in the magnificent historical setting of Somerset House in central London. The Courtauld’s much-loved collection includes paintings, drawings, prints, sculpture and decorative arts ranging from the Renaissance through to the 20th century. The Gallery is renowned for its remarkable group of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist paintings, including the world-famous A Bar at the Folies Bergère by Édouard Manet, Self-Portrait with Bandaged Ear by Vincent van Gogh and the most significant collection of works by Cézanne in the UK. These masterpieces are displayed in The Courtauld’s spectacularly restored LVMH Great Room – London’s oldest purpose-built exhibition space. There are also galleries dedicated to the Medieval and Early Renaissance periods, rooms devoted to 20th century art and the Bloomsbury Group, and dedicated galleries for temporary exhibitions.
category: Speciality & Gift Shops Art Galleries Art Museums
address: Strand Somerset House, London WC2R 0RN England

top_reviews.title: Unique: seeing great art without people taking selfies/iPhone pics in front of you!
top_reviews.review: Our second visit to this museum, each being outstanding. The best part of the Courtauld might be that so few people attend. That means quality time for viewing and considering the displayed art is not interrupted by too many people passing in front of you or taking selfies/iPhone pics of the art work. Absolutely outstanding.

top_reviews.title: My favourite art gallery.
top_reviews.review: This gallery is an absolute gem and probably ranks as my favourite art gallery. It is not huge, so is very manageable for a visit of a couple of hours. The quality of the collection, ranging from medieval to 20th Century, with some wonderful Impressionist and Post-Impressionist works, is amazing. It is nice to leave a galley feeling totally satisfied, but not completely overwhelmed by the size.

top_reviews.title: Delightful
top_reviews.review: My wife and I really enjoyed our visit to the Courtauld gallery. The impressionist collection in particular is well worth a visit with some major pieces by major artists (Degas, van Gogh, Cézanne, Manet, Monet, Morisot). It's also an ideal size, I think it took us maybe 2 hours to go around. The staff were friendly and helpful and the works are very accessible (not many are behind glass). There are free tours and the café is nice (if expensive). I would highly recommend a visit to this gallery. I would also mention that the shop have some lovely and thoughtful products to buy.

top_reviews.title: Impressionists with time to appreciate them
top_reviews.review: A lovely small and quiet cafe. Love the impressionists gallery and you can get close to the pictures to admire them. Not too busy so you can really appreciate the art. Lots of stairs but there is a lift. Good gifts in the shop which you don't need to purchase a ticket for.

top_reviews.title: Truly wonderful.
top_reviews.review: There is no lovelier gallery in London. It is intimate, accessible, romantic, rich in its displays, discreet, serene and its artworks are beautiful beyond words. It is too, that its range of artworks is wide but less expansive than the National Gallery or the Tate. That helps matters. It makes it easier to focus. And what wonderful genius is on display. There is one corner of the Gallery where I could simply stand for hours. Inside one door is a Modigliani nude from 1916, to it's right is Manet's huge Bar at the Folies Bergere and over the shoulder to the right on the wall opposite is the exquisite Van Gogh, La Crau with Peach Trees in Blossom. If you could determine your own eternity, this would surely be one option. I am so grateful for this place.

top_reviews.title: Good Frank Auerbach Exhibition
top_reviews.review: The Courtauld Gallery is situated in Somerset House near Aldwych. It is a short walk from Temple station. This was my first visit here since its refurbishment in late 2021 and I came to see the Frank Auerbach : Charcoal Heads exhibition. This was very good with a couple of dozen interesting works by this fine artist. It was also great to see the permanent collection including old favourites by Manet, Van Gogh, Camille Pissarro and others. I paid £7 with my Art Fund card for admission.

top_reviews.title: Major Collection, Wonderful Presentation
top_reviews.review: The Courtauld's collection is staggering: major works including some of the most important Impressionist paintings, Bloomsbury artists, and contemporary British art work. It's a must see and convenient located in central London. In addition there are also a fine cafe, expansive gift shop, and clean loos. Take the lift to the top and work your way down the spiral staircase.

top_reviews.title: A small gallery with a good collection of impressionist paintings
top_reviews.review: This is not a big gallery and you can see it all in under an hour if there aren't many people there. I was really impressed by the collection of impressionist works on the top floor. The building itself is lovely and they've really curated the works well throughout. Well worth a visit.

top_reviews.title: Lovely art gallery with lots to look at!
top_reviews.review: Lovely gallery with some fantastic pictures ( some very famous!). We had a lovely wander around which took just over an hour although you could stay as long as you want. It wasn't particularly busy which was nice. Also great that students get free entry!

top_reviews.title: Small and Perfectly Formed
top_reviews.review: This was my first visit since its renovation in 2021. As expected the newly revamped rooms are exquisite, affording both a harmonious backdrop to the art and full recognition to the stunning interiors. It is a small museum consisting of a number of substantial bequests and an ongoing acquisitions programme with further bequests incorporated over time. It is particularly strong in impressionist art, but Italian primitives, renaissance, English and Byzantine art are all represented with works of an exceptional standard. The museum is not on the main tourist track (although it's an easy walk from the National Gallery) so it is not overcrowded, which allows viewing at a leisurely pace without constant interruption. Do walk through to the courtyard of Somerset House to view the exterior of the beautiful building. Highly recommended.

name: Madame Tussauds London
description: STARDOM awaits you! Step into the spotlight as you accept your exclusive invitation to Madame Tussauds London, the home of famous fun in the capital. Join your favourite celebs at the ULTIMATE A-list party, strut your stuff on the catwalk with Cara, take the hot seat alongside will.i.am in The Voice Experience or join the Royal Family on the iconic balcony. Test your bravery in Alien: Escape then explore the jungles of Kong: Skull Island. Hail a London cab and journey through 400 years of the capital’s history before joining the Marvel Super Heroes for a crime-fighting adventure. Then use the force to be transported to a galaxy far, far away and star in the action with the greats of the Star Wars universe. So what are you waiting for? COME ON IN!
address: Marylebone Road, London NW1 5LR England

top_reviews.title: Brilliant place to visit. Something for all ages!
top_reviews.review: We really enjoyed it here. Was not sure what to expect as haven’t visited for many years. We visited just after it opened and it was not too busy which was great. There was something for all our family. We particularly liked the chamber of horrors, the marvel film and the Star Wars section. Well worth a visit and relevant for all ages.

top_reviews.title: Interesting but not my favourite thing
top_reviews.review: The wax replicas were very well done. My daughter loved the celebrities, musicians, etc. Enjoyed the cab ride through history. Took the best pictures in Star Wars and Marvel sections. Marvel 4D show was pretty good. Turning up was daunting - 2 really long lines. But we were inside within 10 mins! Didn't see anywhere you could buy tickets at the venue, so glad we bought online in advance.

top_reviews.title: Ideal Place to Visit with anyone!
top_reviews.review: Loved this place the waxworks are so amazing! A great place to visit with your teenagers and something for everyone to relate to ! Particularly enjoyed the Star Wars and Marvel exhibits and the London Taxi ride . Great value for money and not too busy even on a December weekend :-)

top_reviews.title: Good fun
top_reviews.review: It was good coming here after years of not coming. Kids really enjoyed it. Make sure to buy tickets ahead of time, otherwise you could be in line for hours waiting to get in.

top_reviews.title: Fun for all ages! Recommend a visit
top_reviews.review: We were a group of five, three adults and two teenagers, ages between 15-67 years and everyone had an amazing time! I have an autistic 16 year old and he had a sensory overloads midway through, so we asked an employee if they had a quiet room he could rest in for a few minutes, and the response was exemplary! They had a quiet room he was able to rest in, they brought him water and the service was just so great. I’m so grateful for their help and how they handled the situation. After ten minutes we were able to continue our journey through the museum and everyone was happy, the staff told us if there was anything we needed we should just let them know. This was a really positive experience. The museum is huge and the Marvel and Star Wars section was our favorites. Absolutely worth a visit!

top_reviews.title: Hyped expectations and exorbitant entrance fee but great disappointment.
top_reviews.review: This place is supposed to be a must visit for any visitor to London, but was a great disappointment. The entrance is 45 GBP per person which itself is a waste of money. The displays are few and they have removed a number of historically important and famous persons. They have few Hollywood and Bollywood celebrities but nothing else. Only consolation was there was no waiting in the que to enter and there were very few visitors. I am sure the visitor number will go down further unless they improve exhibition and make the entrance fee reasonable especially in this hard times.

top_reviews.title: Fabulous, simply fabulous
top_reviews.review: Madame Tussauds is a very famous place. The figures are so realistic you could fool your friends by saying you met them in real life! Price worth it. Lot to see. Great for families and groups or just solo.

top_reviews.title: Highly recommended!
top_reviews.review: Super cool! This place is huge! It just keeps going and going! I would highly recommend going but try figuring out a time where there isn’t a ton of people, especially if you want to take pictures with the figures! We went in the early afternoon and it was starting to get busy. Highly recommend. We got our tickets as part of a combo pack so you can save money that way!

name: Holland Park
description: Situated west of Kensington Gardens, this city park is particularly attractive in the spring when tulips are in full bloom, and in summer when performances are staged at the open-air theater.
address: Ilchester Place Kensington-Chelsea, London W8 6LU England

top_reviews.title: Beautiful park but attracts some strange people - visitors please don't feed the fish, or birds!!!
top_reviews.review: Visited on a very cold day in January however the scenery was lovely. Really annoying to see people coming to the park with bags full of processed pellets for the fish and chucking the whole bag into the pond. We saw two couples dump a huge amount of 'food' in the space of 10 minutes. If people care so much about the animals, why don't you read the signs or educate yourself on what not to feed them? At the park there were peacocks too which surprised me! Well only two peacocks in the dark which seemed bored and lonely... again, there were groups of people 'feeding' them and making a ruckus.

top_reviews.title: Serene Escape
top_reviews.review: My visit was a delightful experience, filled with picturesque landscapes and tranquil ambiance. The lush greenery and charming pathways provided a serene escape from the hustle and bustle of the city. However, some areas seemed in need of maintenance, slightly detracting from the overall charm. A lovely spot for a leisurely stroll or a quiet moment of reflection.

top_reviews.title: Beautiful park full of surprises
top_reviews.review: A beautiful park in the Kensington Chelsea district that is well cared for with passion and thought. Turn a corner, and another surprise awaits, from the 'wilder' area to the colourful, vibrant borders to the orderly rose gardens. It covers quite a large area and therefore does6appear to be overly busy. There are places to sit and also enjoy refreshments, such as coffee. Ideal for a family visit or simple a private wander. Situated next to the Design Museum, another place worth visiting.

top_reviews.title: Lunch and a stroll
top_reviews.review: One of my favourite parks to walk around in London. So much so see and walk around and enjoy. It was a sunny day and it was lovely to spend a few hours there eating lunch and having a stroll. Peacocks in the botanical gardens love putting on a show, theyre beautiful. Great visit.

name: Museum Of Brands
description: Just around the corner from the world-famous Portobello Road Market stands a unique, Aladdin's cave of retro design and memories - the only museum of its kind in the whole world. Imagine walking through a corridor full from floor to ceiling with the treats that the British have filled their shopping baskets with for the last 200 years. Every corner you turn in the Time Tunnel leads you into a different decade. Discover what has made shoppers tick for the last 200 years and surround yourself in the classic designs, vintage adverts and retro stylings that fill our museum. The Museum is available to hire for evening events and there's a fabulous conference room for daytime events! So whether you visit to awaken childhood memories or to inspire your own designs, we welcome you to the Museum of Brands. Please see our website for the latest information on exhibitions and activities.
address: 111-117 Lancaster Road Notting Hill, London W11 1QT England

top_reviews.title: Fantastic
top_reviews.review: What a brilliant collection across the decades. Great for couples or families and great value for money. You can whizz around in an hour if you are short of time, or spend 2+ hours exploring every display in detail. Some interesting facts about the early years and an amazing collection of memorabilia for all ages. I never knew you could get Lobster soup in a tin at one time!

top_reviews.title: Fascinating museum
top_reviews.review: Came to this museum with little expectations and was really blown away. They show you how consumer culture started from the Victorian era to today. It talks about how historical events have influenced/created products, which was fascinating. You’re also able to see how common household brands have evolved over time. Very informative and highly recommend this as a visit! There’s even a nice little cafe at the end.

top_reviews.title: Fantastic Aladdins Cave
top_reviews.review: Ive been wanting to visit this museum for some time, but it havent been able to until a recent visit. I was expecting a trip down memory lane with a little brand nostalgia. It was far far better than I had expected. I loved every minute of it. Its a fantastic place to visit and something for everyone. It would be nice if the gift shop had got some reproduced items for sale, but do understand the manufacturing cost maybe more than a shopper may want to pay

top_reviews.title: Yes!
top_reviews.review: I so enjoyed my visit to the Museum of Brands. I wasn't expecting to like it so much, but I was absolutely fascinated by it. It's kind of sensory overload and you maybe need to be a certain kind of person to be into it, but I really liked it. Well worth the £10 or whatever!

top_reviews.title: Brand-tastic!
top_reviews.review: A fascinating trip down memory lane. Who knew that looking at old drinks cans, wrappers and packets could evoke so many memories! The time tunnel was great ranging from Victorian to the present day - you tend to linger more on the decade you grew up in I suppose. 80s child! I found the exhibition space most interesting with the UK’s top 100 brands section and a focus on the changing packaging of particular products - Matey bubble bath and harpic! Spent a few hours here - only slight issue was the sheer amount of things to look at was quite overwhelming and I needed a good lie down afterwards!

top_reviews.title: great place
top_reviews.review: lovely little museum, really interesting. Showcasing brands from the 1800's to present day. Really takes you back. There were regular shouts of 'ooh, look at that' and 'do you remember them?' well worth a visit. Well away from the usual hustle and bustle of museum land not far from Notting Hill.

top_reviews.title: Hidden gem of West London
top_reviews.review: The timeline layout of the museum was a joy to follow. Such a huge collection of many different brands ranging from food packaging, toys, music and events in british history. If you are a designer/creative/product designer then you really do need to visit. It's amazing to see how some of the countries most iconic brands have changed over time. Visited during the week so this added to the experience as you weren't rushed around. Nice little cafe and gift shop at the entrance/exit too. Please visit and support this space.

top_reviews.title: The Best Little Museum Around
top_reviews.review: This fun and quirky museum is like no other in Britain. It began as a private collection but has grown into a thoughtful look at how we live through the objects we buy. It's like stepping into a time capsule to see household goods from everyday life repackaged over the years to keep a brand fresh and sought-after. Toys, vinyl records, food and drink all feature. Treat yourself!

top_reviews.title: Fun
top_reviews.review: Really enjoyed this museum. One of the best in London. Loved how it is chronologically arranged and the older decades in particular were fascinating to see and read about. We spent two hours going round as there’s just so much to see if you take your time. Cost £10 per adult ticket and it’s a bargain.

top_reviews.title: You must visit here!
top_reviews.review: What an incredible place! Spent a few days in London, and a true highlight was the Museum of Brands! So many memories! Icing on the cake was meeting the founder Robert Opie during the walk around. What an incredible person to have such vision and passion to have created such a wonderful collection. We will be back! And will 100% recommend a visit to friends & family….plus great little gift shop, cafe & garden.

name: Garden at 120
description: Temporarily Closed
address: 120 Fenchurch Street, London EC3M 5AL England

top_reviews.title: Nice views and well-maintained grounds
top_reviews.review: Visited on a weekday during November 2023. No advance booking required. Breezed through security and onto the 15th floor, with practically no queues and no fuss. The grounds are well-maintained with good views over London. Although slightly obscured by taller buildings, the views are 360 degrees in an open air environment. Far less crowded in comparison to the nearby Sky Garden (which also requires advance booking). Would recommend.

top_reviews.title: Very cool!
top_reviews.review: A lovely space with beautiful views. We enjoyed a bottle of wine in the restaurant. Bit pricey but worth it. Lovely atmosphere. Don’t quite understand why they want to keep your bottle of wine when you have bought it away from you! We like an eye on our drink and to fill up our glass when we want. They couldn’t keep up with us so we ended up with empty glasses so in the end we just asked for it on the table.

top_reviews.title: Wonderful addition to the City
top_reviews.review: Visited twice in June 2023. Only found out it existed from a hidden gems TikTok, initially on a walk from Monument to Leadenhall Market then past the Lloyds Building to The Garden at 120. The second time straight from Fenchurch Street Station. No tickets/pre-booking are required, just rock up to a nondescript building with a large open area at the base and a wonderful animated ceiling. There is a security check and then you just queue to go up in the lift. There is a restaurant/cafe one floor down from the roof, but nothing on the actual roof though you can sit and eat whatever you bring I believe. The roof is decorated with flower beds, water features and seating. There are panoramic views all around, up and down the Thames, as well as the City/Gerkin. A wonderful/budget-friendly addition to any journey to the City.

top_reviews.title: Great views of London
top_reviews.review: Spent a few days in London and came here to see the London skyline and the views were amazing as the sun was setting. Open top rooftop where you can see iconic buildings like the Shard, Tower Bridge, Walkie Talkie and The Gherkin to name a few. There was initially a queue and security check which I thought would take time but surprisingly everything was done quick and efficiently.

top_reviews.title: Great Views at 120
top_reviews.review: Nice open top rooftop with amazing views of London landmarks. Nice calm place to chill with your friends or family when you visit London. Seeing London skyline at night and the green spaces illuminated had a nice ambience.

top_reviews.title: Great find for views of Tower Bridge
top_reviews.review: Great find- although there was a bit of a queue it moved pretty fast and was less than 10 minutes.So quiet and peaceful in the garden and a really lovely space. Got a lovely coffee there too. Views pretty good but definitely shadowed by the Sky Garden building. Worth a visit

top_reviews.title: Amazing experience
